title: Childless people will not get new inheritance tax break, Government confirms
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Sep 10, 2015, 09:47 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 43 mins Childless people will not get new inheritance tax break, Government confirms By Richard Dyson | Telegraph – 12 minutes ago 0.0001 0.0000 
David Gauke insists the extra £350,000 'family home' inheritance tax allowance per couple won't go to those without children 
The Government has made clear that the special inheritance tax concession for family homes will not be made available to people who have no children, despite significant protests. 
The "family home allowance" is the mechanism by which a married couple's joint £650,000 inheritance tax exemption is extended to £1m with an extra allowance applicable only to the family home. 
Each spouse will have a separate £175,000 allowance (£350,000 combined) on top of their individual £325,000 allowance. This is to be phased in. 
But, crucially, it applies only where the family home is bequeathed to children, grandchildren, stepchildren or adopted children. So a couple with no children effectively face a £140,000 bill (40pc death tax applied to £350,000) that couples with children would not have to pay. 
• Inheritance tax: why should childless couples (and their heirs) pay £140,000 more? 
We first publicised the issue on August 8, prompted by a growing stream of letters and emails from readers dismayed by the exclusion. 
One of our readers, among the many to complain to his MP, has now received a written response from David Gauke, financial secretary to the Treasury. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) said: "The Prime Minister and Chancellor of the Exchequer have both highlighted that when you become a parent, the wish to pass something on is the most basic, human and natural instinct there is. 
"Focusing the policy on children and grandchildren ensures parents know that they will be able to pass on the family home that they have worked hard for to the next generation without the worry of inheritance tax." 
Mr Gauke added that "around 80pc of estates with both a residence and an inheritance tax liability are expected to be in a position to benefit".
